array.string: the uppermost register, above the traditional range of the instrument. On saxophone, this is generally above F or F#, depending on the instrument’s keywork
refers to a particular range of voice, second highest of the standard four voice ranges between soprano and tenor
moderately slow but moving, walking tempo
refers to a particular range of voice, the lowest of all the standard four voice ranges
the pronounced rhythm of music; one single stroke of a rhythmic accent
the time signature 4/4, four beats per measure
with; used in very many musical directions, for example con allegrezza (with liveliness), con amore (with tenderness)
with fire, in a fiery manner
Same as the meter 2/2: two half-note (minim) beats per measure
finished, closed; i.e., a rest or note is to be held for a duration that is at the discretion of the performer or conductor
a symbol (♭) that lowers the pitch of a note by a semitone
instruction to play a note with strong, sudden emphasis
somewhat slowly; not as slow as largo
in a smooth and connected manner
in a majestic and stately manner
marked; i.e., with accentuation, execute every note as if it were to be accented
the period of a musical piece that encompasses a complete cycle of the time signature
a symbol that cancels the effect of a sharp or a flat
natural; i.e., discontinue a special effect
extremely quickly, as fast as possible
slightly speeding up or slowing down the tempo of a piece at the discretion of the soloist or the conductor; to rob
instruction to play a note with strong, sudden emphasis
a symbol (♯) that raises the pitch of the note by a semitone
similarly; i.e., continue applying the preceding directive
executed by more than one player or voice
alone; i.e., executed by a single instrument or voice
refers to a particular range of voice, the highest of the standard four voice ranges
making each note brief and detached, cut short and crisp
time, the speed of a piece of music
So as to be held for the full time value; sustained
refers to a particular range of voice, second lowest of the standard four voice ranges between alto and bass
vibrating, rapidly repeating slight alteration in the pitch of a note
dance written in triple time, where the accent falls on the first beat of each measure
